sub_topic: Probability of a certain type of crime occurring in a neighborhood
message_1: A certain type of crime occurs in a neighborhood with a probability of 0.2. What is the probability that this crime will occur exactly 3 times in a randomly selected sample of 20 incidents in the neighborhood?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the binomial probability formula, which is:

P(X = k) = C(n, k) * p^k * (1-p)^(n-k)

where:
- P(X = k) is the probability of exactly k successes (in this case, the crime occurring exactly 3 times)
- C(n, k) is the number of combinations of n items taken k at a time (also written as nCk or "n choose k")
- n is the number of trials (in this case, 20 incidents)
- k is the number of successes (in this case, 3 crimes)
- p is the probability of success (in this case, 0.2)
- (1-p) is the probability of failure (in this case, 1 - 0.2 = 0.8)

First, we need to calculate C(20, 3), which is the number of combinations of 20 incidents taken 3 at a time:

C(20, 3) = 20! / (3! * (20-3)!)
C(20, 3) = 20! / (3! * 17!)
C(20, 3) = (20 * 19 * 18 * 17!)/(3! * 17!)
C(20, 3) = (20 * 19 * 18)/(3 * 2 * 1)
C(20, 3) = 1140

Now, we can plug the values into the binomial probability formula:

P(X = 3) = C(20, 3) * 0.2^3 * 0.8^(20-3)
P(X = 3) = 1140 * 0.2^3 * 0.8^17
P(X = 3) = 1140 * 0.008 * 0.0223 (rounded to 4 decimal places)
P(X = 3) â‰ˆ 0.2035 (rounded to 4 decimal places)

So, the probability that this crime will occur exactly 3 times in a randomly selected sample of 20 incidents in the neighborhood is approximately 0.2035 or 20.35%.
